abstract.p: Paul MacDonald letter disputes Jeffrey Rosen's April 30 article on Internet privacy and describes how he protects his own privacy

block.p: I fail to see the connection between a business Web site that appends a ''cookie'' to my orders (to improve its ability to provide quality customer service) and Rosen's broader concerns over the erosion of privacy.

I use the Internet to buy books and music quickly, to do academic research and to keep in touch with friends in distant places. The rule of thumb I use to protect my privacy when online is simple: I save my intimate life for the bedroom and my off-color rants for the barroom, and I keep my personal life out of chat rooms.
